summary.long: Nahum is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: An oracle concerning Nineveh. The book of the vision of Nahum of Elkosh.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord is slow to anger and great in power,
    and the Lord will by no means clear the guilty.
His way is in whirlwind and storm,
    and the clouds are the dust of his feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Who can stand before his indignation?
    Who can endure the heat of his anger?
His wrath is poured out like fire,
    and the rocks are broken into pieces by him.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
But with an overflowing flood
he will make a complete end of the adversaries,
    and will pursue his enemies into darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
From you came one
    who plotted evil against the Lord,
    a worthless counsellor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Thus says the Lord,
“Though they are at full strength and many,
    they will be cut down and pass away.
Though I have afflicted you,
    I will afflict you no more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And now I will break his yoke from off you
    and will burst your bonds apart.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord has given commandment about you:
    “No more shall your name be perpetuated;
from the house of your gods I will cut off
    the carved image and the metal image.
I will make your grave, for you are vile.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Behold, upon the mountains, the feet of him
    who brings good news,
    who publishes peace!
Keep your feasts, O Judah;
    fulfil your vows,
for never again shall the worthless pass through you;
    he is utterly cut off.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
For the Lord is restoring the majesty of Jacob
    as the majesty of Israel,
for plunderers have plundered them
    and ruined their branches.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
The river gates are opened;
    the palace melts away;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
its mistress is stripped; she is carried off,
    her slave girls lamenting,
moaning like doves
    and beating their breasts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Nineveh is like a pool
    whose waters run away.
“Halt! Halt!” they cry,
    but none turns back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Plunder the silver,
    plunder the gold!
There is no end of the treasure
    or of the wealth of all precious things.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Where is the lions' den,
    the feeding place of the young lions,
where the lion and lioness went,
    where his cubs were, with none to disturb?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The lion tore enough for his cubs
    and strangled prey for his lionesses;
he filled his caves with prey
    and his dens with torn flesh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Behold, I am against you, declares the Lord of hosts, and I will burn your chariots in smoke, and the sword shall devour your young lions. I will cut off your prey from the earth, and the voice of your messengers shall no longer be heard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Woe to the bloody city,
    all full of lies and plunder—
    no end to the prey!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The crack of the whip, and rumble of the wheel,
    galloping horse and bounding chariot!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Horsemen charging,
    flashing sword and glittering spear,
hosts of slain,
    heaps of corpses,
dead bodies without end—
    they stumble over the bodies!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And all for the countless whorings of the prostitute,
    graceful and of deadly charms,
who betrays nations with her whorings,
    and peoples with her charms.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Behold, I am against you,
    declares the Lord of hosts,
    and will lift up your skirts over your face;
and I will make nations look at your nakedness
    and kingdoms at your shame.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I will throw filth at you
    and treat you with contempt
    and make you a spectacle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
And all who look at you will shrink from you and say,
Wasted is Nineveh; who will grieve for her?
    Where shall I seek comforters for you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Are you better than Thebes
    that sat by the Nile,
with water round her,
    her rampart a sea,
    and water her wall?
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
All your fortresses are like fig trees
    with first-ripe figs—
if shaken they fall
    into the mouth of the eater.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Behold, your troops
    are women in your midst.
The gates of your land
    are wide open to your enemies;
    fire has devoured your bars.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
You increased your merchants
    more than the stars of the heavens.
    The locust spreads its wings and flies away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your princes are like grasshoppers,
    your scribes like clouds of locusts
settling on the fences
    in a day of cold—
when the sun rises, they fly away;
    no one knows where they are.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your shepherds are asleep,
    O king of Assyria;
    your nobles slumber.
Your people are scattered on the mountains
    with none to gather them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There is no easing your hurt;
    your wound is grievous.
All who hear the news about you
    clap their hands over you.
For upon whom has not come
    your unceasing evil?
verses.speaker: Narrator
